elements.content: The molecular structures of Li2[Ni(tmdta)]·5H2O (1a, tmdta = trimethylenediaminetetraacetate), {C(NH2)3}2[Ni(tmdta)]·6H2O (1b), and {Ni(H2O)6}[Ni(tmdta)]·2H2O (2a) have been determined. The central trimethylenediamine chelate ring shows half-chair (hc) geometries in 1a and 1b, while a twist-boat (tb) conformation is encountered in 2a. The coexistence of tb and hc forms in the solid state prompted us to elucidate the existence of a tb ⇌ hc equilibrium in aqueous solution. Evaluation of the data from solid state vibrational spectra (Raman and IR) for the hc and tb forms showed excellent agreement with simulated spectra obtained with DFT computations (TPSSh/TZVP). This outstanding matching between theory and experiment enabled us to build composite spectra with varying hc:tb ratios. Comparison of these results with Raman and IR spectra recorded for [Ni(tmdta)]2– in aqueous solution revealed that simulated Raman and IR spectra with a hc:tb ratio = 2:3 match the solution spectra in an accurate way. This equilibrium ratio enabled us to compute 13C NMR sifts for the paramagnetic solution spectrum of [Ni(tmdta)]2– based on the relative contributions by hc and tb fractions. This leads to computed shifts that agree closely with the experimental ones. Also, the kinetics of the skeleton dynamics could be estimated quantitatively by temperature-dependent 13C NMR spectroscopic measurements. An interesting effect encountered for the very first time here concerns a drastic intensity difference of the 10Dq band (3A2g → 3T2g(F) transition) in solid state electronic spectra of tb vs hc isomers, where the intensity of this band in the case of the hc form is much lower than that of the tb conformer and thus more similar to the case of the usual NiII chromophore in octahedral environment. The equilibrium constants for complex formation and protonation of NiII–tmdta at low pH have been estimated by pH-dependent UV–vis titration experiments. Correlation of these data with those of NiII–edta and related 3d MII edta and tmdta complexes allow important conclusions on the consequences resulting from extending the central diamine ring in the ligand by one methylene group in terms of both complex and protolytic stability for edta vs tmdta complexes.

elements.content: The coexistence of twist-boat (tb) and half-chair (hc) conformers in aqueous solutions of [Ni(tmdta)]2− has been proved by a combination of vibrational (IR and Raman) and NMR spectroscopies supported by DFT computations. Outstanding matching between theory and experiment made it possible to estimate a hc:tb ratio of 2:3 for the solutions at room temperature. The kinetics of the skeleton dynamics was estimated quantitatively by temperature-dependent 13C NMR spectroscopic measurements.

Outstanding matching between theory and experiment made it possible to estimate a hc:tb ratio of 2:3 for the solutions at room temperature. The kinetics of the skeleton dynamics was estimated quantitatively by temperature-dependent 13C NMR spectroscopic measurements.

elements.content: Polyaminocarboxylate ligands such as edta and related systems are efficient chelating agents used in laundry, textile, and paper industries to remove different metal ions. Edta is also used as an additive in food and beverages, cosmetics and personal care products, and cleansing agents. Furthermore, edta is utilized for chelation treatment of metal intoxication to treat poisoning with heavy metals such as lead.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Polyaminocarboxylate ligands such as edta and related systems are efficient chelating agents used in laundry, textile, and paper industries to remove different metal ions. Edta is also used as an additive in food and beverages, cosmetics and personal care products, and cleansing agents. Furthermore, edta is utilized for chelation treatment of metal intoxication to treat poisoning with heavy metals such as lead.

elements.content: Replacement of the ethylene bridge in edta by a propylene spacer to give tmdta was shown to have significant effects on the structure and reactivity of the corresponding metal complexes. Complex formation with tmdta as compared to edta leads to formation of a six-membered instead of a five-membered chelate ring (see Scheme ) in the central diamine branch of the corresponding complexes. While a regular symmetric gauche-type conformation of the diamine chelate ring (E ring) is usually found in six-coordinate edta complex structures, two different ring conformations are a priori possible in the diamine chelate ring (T ring) of a tmdta complex: Twist-boat (tb) and half-chair (hc) (cf. Scheme ). The structure adopted by a particular complex in solution may have a dramatic impact on its properties. For instance, lanthanide complexes with the polyaminocarboxylate ligand dota (1,4,7,10-tetraazacyclododecane-1,4,7,10-tetraacetate) are known to exist in solution as two diastereoisomeric forms (m and M) that differ by the layout of their acetate arms. However, it took almost 20 years after the first studies on these complexes to discover that water exchange of the coordinated water molecule, a key parameter that controls their efficiency as MRI contrast agents, is about 2 orders of magnitude faster on the m isomer than on the M form. The conformation adopted in solution by transition metal complexes was also found to play an important role in their efficiency catalyzing certain reactions (i.e., peptide hydrolysis) or in their ability to bind biological substrates. Thus, understanding the isomeric composition of a particular complex in solution and the factors that control it is of great importance to design chelates with the desired properties in a rational way. However, in the particular case of tmdta complexes the factors that govern the populations of tb and hc isomers remain largely unexplored, so that the approach presented here is an advent to clarify this query.

elements.content: Inspection of the current version of the CCDC structural database (conquest 1.15, 2013) concerning adoption of hc or tb geometries in T rings of solid state tmdta complex structures reveals the following picture: One finds 34 independent structure estimations with 19 tb and 14 hc structures. The following structures with 3d MIII ions contain a pure T ring with tb conformations in six-coordinate complexes: K[Co(tmdta)]·2H2O and a related CoIII complex, the series of isostructural sodium salts Na[M(tmdta)]·3H2O with M = CrIII, RhIII, FeIII, and VIII as well as K[GaIII(tmdta)]·3H2O. Recently, structures of K[Fe(tmdta)], {C(NH2)3}[Fe(tmdta)]·3H2O, and NH4[Fe(tmdta)]·0.5H2O were published containing also tb diamine fragments.

elements.content: Complex structures of tmdta with MII ions and tb conformations in six-coordinate complexes were found in the isostructural series with the general formula {Ma(H2O)6}[Mb(tmdta)]·2H2O where Ma = Mb in {Co(H2O)6}[Co(tmdta)]·2H2O and {Zn(H2O)6}[Zn(tmdta)]·2H2O as well as in {Mg(H2O)6}[Mg(tmdta)]·2H2O. In the other structures belonging to this series, Ma is Mg throughout and the structures are {Mg(H2O)6}[Ni(tmdta)]·2H2O, {Mg(H2O)6}[Cu(tmdta)]·2H2O, {Mg(H2O)6}[Co(tmdta)]·2H2O, {Mg(H2O)6}[Zn(tmdta)]·2H2O, as well as {Mn(H2O)6}[Cu(tmdta)]·2H2O, where Ma = Mn. The salt {Mg(H2O)6}[Mg0.5Mn0.5(tmdta)]·2H2O also with a tb T ring is an exception containing Mg and Mn equally distributed in the complex anion and can be regarded as a six-coordinate form of the MnII–tmdta system. However, compound {Mg(H2O)6}[Mn(tmdta)(H2O)]·2H2O contains a seven-coordinate MnII center and a hc-configured T ring.

In the other structures belonging to this series, Ma is Mg throughout and the structures are {Mg(H2O)6}[Ni(tmdta)]⋅2H2O, {Mg(H2O)6}[Cu(tmdta)]⋅2H2O, {Mg(H2O)6}[Co(tmdta)]⋅2H2O, {Mg(H2O)6}[Zn(tmdta)]⋅2H2O, as well as {Mn(H2O)6}[Cu(tmdta)]⋅2H2O, where Ma = Mn. The salt {Mg(H2O)6}[Mg0.5Mn0.5(tmdta)]⋅2H2O also with a tb T ring is an exception containing Mg and Mn equally distributed in the complex anion and can be regarded as a six-coordinate form of the MnII-tmdta system. However, compound {Mg(H2O)6}[Mn(tmdta)(H2O)]⋅2H2O contains a seven-coordinate MnII center and a hc-configured T ring.

elements.content: Complexes with coordination numbers (CNs) higher than 6 (7, 8, and 9) do not adopt the tb conformation, and the hc conformation is adopted throughout, which indicates that the latter fits much better to the geometric requirements of higher CNs. In addition to the complexes containing the MnII–OH2 fragment, there is another MII complex showing CN 7 with CdII as the central ion with identical composition to its MnII relative, i.e., {Mg(H2O)6}[Cd(tmdta)(H2O)]·2H2O. The remaining MII–tmdta complex contains an eight-coordinate CaII center in [Ca(H2O)3{Ca(tmdta)(H2O)]·2H2O, which is the complex formula in the original paper. This structure contains a double μ-aqua-bridged tmdta complex dimer [{Ca(tmdta)(μ-H2O)}2]4– with partially aquated calcium counter cations. The series of rare earth tmdta complex structures has been reported by Jun Wang and co-workers. It is interesting that the whole series of CN 8 LnIII–tmdta complexes contains infinite chains of complex anions bridged by carboxylato groups with a μ2-carboxylato-syn-anti bridging mode, and the coordination sphere is completed by one coordinated water molecule. There is one exception from this behavior found in the YbIII monomer NH4[Yb(tmdta)(H2O)2]·5H2O. Thus far, only one structure with an LnIII-center exceeding CN 8 was found, the SmIII dimer in K2[{Sm(μ2-tmdta)(H2O)2}2]·4.79H2O, where the samarium centers are bound to two water molecules and are additionally doubly carboxylato bridged (bis(μ-η1-carboxylato)), giving rise to a 10-coordinated complex.

elements.content: Not mentioned so far are the group of Li+ salts Li[Fe(tmdta)]·3H2O and Li2[Co(tmdta)]·5H2O. The latter adopts a hc conformation, while Li[Fe(tmdta)]·3H2O is essentially hc in the solid state. However, as outlined in a re-estimation of its structure, a minor fraction of 8.7% tb does coexist in the presence of 91.3% hc. In the same way, the structure of {C(NH2)3}[Fe(tmdta)]·2H2O is also peculiar, as 94% tb form is present with a minor fraction of 6% hc. The main goal of the present study is thus to elucidate the solution structure of the NiII–tmdta system, in particular addressing the possible presence of a tb ⇌ hc equilibrium in solution. Thus, we have chosen Li+ and {C(NH2)3}+ as counter cations for salt preparations with the aim to isolate hc isomers in the solid state. This was planned because when our study was started only the crystal structure of {Mg(H2O)6}[Ni(tmdta)]·2H2O (2b) was known in which the central diamine chelate ring adopts a tb conformation as described above. The strategy that we intended to adopt for our investigation is essentially identical to the approach applied in a previous work: Solid and aqueous solution structures were studied by vibrational spectroscopy (IR and Raman), supported by calculated IR and Raman spectra using density functional theory (DFT). Furthermore, a 13C NMR study combined with DFT calculations was used to explore the kinetics of the interconversions in the chelate rings accompanying the tb ⇌ hc equilibrium reactions. Finally, theoretical calculations of the contact 13C NMR shifts were used to determine accurately the population of the tb and hc conformers in solution.

elements.content: Note that our approach to prepare [Ni(tmdta)]2– salts is completely different to that used by Radanovic et al. to prepare the closely related [Mg(H2O)6][Ni(tmdta)]·2H2O (2b) salt. Our approach avoided the use of column chromatography because the ligand was prepared directly in the form of the free acid H4tmdta or was used in that form from commercial sources (Sigma-Aldrich).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental and Computational Section

Materials and Methods

Preparations

Note that our approach to prepare [Ni(tmdta)]2- salts is completely different to that used by Radanovic et al. to prepare the closely related [Mg(H2O)6][Ni(tmdta)]⋅2H2O (2b) salt. Our approach avoided the use of column chromatography because the ligand was prepared directly in the form of the free acid H4tmdta or was used in that form from commercial sources (Sigma-Aldrich).

elements.content: A suspension of H4tmdta (3.06 g, 0.01 mol) in 20 mL of water was heated with stirring to 70 °C. After addition of a first portion of Li2CO3 (0.01 mol, 0.74 g), a clear solution resulted. Then 3.66 g (0.01 mol) of Ni(ClO4)2·6H2O was added under stirring. A second portion of Li2CO3 (0.01 mol, 0.74 g) was added (one has to be careful during both additions of Li2CO3 because of the very intensive development of CO2!), and heating was continued for 1 h. The resulting blue solution was placed in the refrigerator. After a period of several days, greenish-blue crystals were formed. These were collected by suction filtration and washed with cold water and ethanol. Recrystallization was carried out from a water–ethanol mixture. Yield: 3.7 g (80%). Anal. Calcd for C11H24Li2N2NiO13 (464.9): C, 33.58; H, 7.81; N, 6.03. Found: C, 33.50; H, 7.86; N, 6.00. Single crystals suitable for X-ray structure determination were prepared in the following way: A concentrated aqueous solution of 1 was gently layered with the 3-fold volume of ethanol in a large reagent glass. Crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction formed after several days. These were removed by hand picking.

elements.content: A suspension of H4tmdta (3.06 g, 0.01 mol) in 30 mL of water was heated with stirring to 70 °C. A 2.9 g amount (0.01 mol) of [Ni(H2O)6]·2NO3 was added to this solution, which gave in a short moment a turquoise blue solution. After stirring for further 10 min at 70 °C, the solution was cooled to room temperature. Then, a 3.6 g amount of {C(NH2)3}CO3 (0.02 mol) was gently added to the solution in portions, which resulted in a color change to clear deep blue. Standing of the clear solution at room temperature over 2 days led to the separation of clear, deep blue crystals, which were separated by filtration. Yield: 5.0 g (85%). Anal. Calcd for C13H38NiN8O14 (589.2): C, 26.50; H, 6.50; N, 19.02. Found: C, 26.48; H, 6.63; N, 18.89. Single crystals suitable for X-ray structure determination were prepared in the following way: A concentrated aqueous solution of 1b was set aside in a Petri dish. Crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction formed after 1 week.

elements.content: This solid formed accidently during a trial to prepare 1b where only one-half of the amount of {C(NH2)3}CO3 was added. Therefore, the procedure to make 2a is completely identical to that of 1b except that 1.8 g (0.01 mol) of {C(NH2)3}CO3 was added to a solution containing H4tmdta (3.06 g, 0.01 mol) and 2.9 g (0.01 mol) of [Ni(H2O)6]·2NO3 in 30 mL of water. Crystals formed after 1 week of standing of this solution, had a regular shape, and were suitable for structural analysis. Yield: 4.5 g (80%). Anal. Calcd for C11H30N2Ni2O16 (563.8): C, 23.44; H, 5.36; N, 4.97. Found: C, 23.36; H, 5.42; N, 4.93.

elements.content: A suspension of H4tmdta (3.06 g, 0.01 mol) in 20 mL of water was heated with stirring to 70 °C. After addition of a first portion of MgCO3·3H2O (0.01 mol, 1.38 g), a clear solution resulted. Subsequently, 3.66 g (0.01 mol) of Ni(ClO4)2·6H2O was added under stirring. A second portion of MgCO3·3H2O (0.01 mol, 1.38 g) was added. After carbon dioxide formation ceased, a deep blue solution resulted. This was layered with a solution of ethanol until the first turbidity appears and placed then in a refrigerator. A crystalline solid formed after 3 days, which was collected by vacuum filtration. Yield: 4.7 g (89%). Anal. Calcd for C11H30MgN2NiO16 (529.4): C, 24.96; H, 5.71; N, 5.29. Found: C, 24.89; H, 5.77; N, 5.25.

[Mg(H2O)6][Ni(tmdta)]⋅2H2O (2b)

A suspension of H4tmdta (3.06 g, 0.01 mol) in 20 mL of water was heated with stirring to 70 °C. After addition of a first portion of MgCO3⋅3H2O (0.01 mol, 1.38 g), a clear solution resulted. Subsequently, 3.66 g (0.01 mol) of Ni(ClO4)2⋅6H2O was added under stirring. A second portion of MgCO3⋅3H2O (0.01 mol, 1.38 g) was added. After carbon dioxide formation ceased, a deep blue solution resulted. This was layered with a solution of ethanol until the first turbidity appears and placed then in a refrigerator. A crystalline solid formed after 3 days, which was collected by vacuum filtration. Yield: 4.7 g (89%). Anal. Calcd for C11H30MgN2NiO16 (529.4): C, 24.96; H, 5.71; N, 5.29. Found: C, 24.89; H, 5.77; N, 5.25.

elements.content: A 930 mg amount of Li2[Ni(tmdta)]·5H2O was dissolved in D2O (1 mL, solution concentration 2 M) and filled into a 5 mm NMR tube. Variable-temperature 25.2 MHz 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker AC 100 NMR spectrometer at 293, 333, 353, and 373 K. For each spectrum 100 000 scans were acquired using a 0.5 s recycle time with a spectral width of 1600 ppm and the transmitter frequency centered at −200 ppm. The FIDs were treated with an exponential window function with 50 Hz line broadening prior to Fourier transformation. Resulting spectra were referenced against trimethylsilyl propionate (TSP) as an external standard.
elements.clean_text:
NMR Measurements

A 930 mg amount of Li2[Ni(tmdta)]⋅5H2O was dissolved in D2O (1 mL, solution concentration 2 M) and filled into a 5 mm NMR tube. Variable-temperature 25.2 MHz 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker AC 100 NMR spectrometer at 293, 333, 353, and 373 K. For each spectrum 100000 scans were acquired using a 0.5 s recycle time with a spectral width of 1600 ppm and the transmitter frequency centered at -200 ppm. The FIDs were treated with an exponential window function with 50 Hz line broadening prior to Fourier transformation. Resulting spectra were referenced against trimethylsilyl propionate (TSP) as an external standard.

elements.clean_text:
Raman Spectra

Raman spectra of solid samples were recorded with a BRUKER IFS 66 device, while spectra of complexes in aqueous solutions were measured with a JOBIN YVON Ramanor HG 2S. In both cases, the 457.9 nm line of an argon laser was applied as an excitation source.

elements.content: Crystal data and experimental details are compiled in Table S1 (). Suitable single crystals were sealed in glass capillaries. Intensity data were collected at 294(2) K on a Nicolet R3m/V four-circle diffractometer (Mo Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å, graphite monochromator, ω scans) up to 2Θmax= 64° or on a STOE IPDS I image-plate system at 200 K. A numeric absorption correction was applied for 1b and 2a. A semiempirical absorption correction using ψ scans was applied. Both structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full matrix least-squares procedures based on F 2 with all unique reflections (SHELXTL NT 5.10). All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. All hydrogen atoms were located in a difference Fourier map and refined isotropically. Both the positional parameters and a common isotropic displacement parameter have been kept fixed during the refinement.
elements.clean_text:
Structure Determinations

Crystal data and experimental details are compiled in Table S1 (). Suitable single crystals were sealed in glass capillaries. Intensity data were collected at 294(2) K on a Nicolet R3m/V four-circle diffractometer (Mo Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å, graphite monochromator, ω scans) up to 2Θmax= 64° or on a STOE IPDS I image-plate system at 200 K. A numeric absorption correction was applied for 1b and 2a. A semiempirical absorption correction using ψ scans was applied. Both structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full matrix least-squares procedures based on F 2 with all unique reflections (SHELXTL NT 5.10). All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. All hydrogen atoms were located in a difference Fourier map and refined isotropically. Both the positional parameters and a common isotropic displacement parameter have been kept fixed during the refinement.

elements.content: All calculations presented in this work were performed employing the Gaussian 09 package (Revision A.01). Full geometry optimizations of the [Ni(tmdta)]2– and [Zn(tmdta)]2– systems were performed in aqueous solution employing DFT within the hybrid meta-GGA approximation with the TPSSh exchange-correlation functional. Input geometries were generated from the corresponding crystallographic data. In these calculations we used the standard Ahlrichs’ valence triple-ξ including polarization functions (TZVP). No symmetry constraints have been imposed during the optimizations. In the case of NiII complexes the highest spin state was considered as the ground state (triplet). Since these calculations performed on the [Ni(tmdta)]2– complex used an unrestricted model, spin contamination was assessed by a comparison of the expected difference between S(S + 1) for the assigned spin state (S(S + 1) = 2.0 for the mononuclear NiII complexes investigated here) and the actual value of ⟨S 2⟩. The results obtained indicate that spin contamination is negligible for systems investigated in this work [⟨S 2⟩ – S(S + 1) ≈ 0.0030]. The stationary points found on potential energy surfaces as a result of geometry optimizations were tested to represent energy minima rather than saddle points via frequency analysis. Default values for the integration grid (75 radial shells and 302 angular points) and the SCF energy convergence criteria (10–8) were used in all calculations. The interconversions between the twist-boat (tb) and half-chair (hc) forms and the exchange between in-plane and out-of-plane glycinate rings of [Ni(tmdta)]2– were investigated by means of the synchronous transit-guided quasi-Newton method. The nature of the saddle points (one imaginary frequency) was characterized by frequency analysis. The relative free energies of the two energy minima and the free energy barrier for their interconversion were calculated in aqueous solution at the TPSSh/TZVP level, and they include non-potential-energy contributions (zero-point energies and thermal terms) obtained through frequency analysis.
elements.clean_text:
Theoretical and Computational Details

All calculations presented in this work were performed employing the Gaussian 09 package (Revision A.01). Full geometry optimizations of the [Ni(tmdta)]2- and [Zn(tmdta)]2- systems were performed in aqueous solution employing DFT within the hybrid meta-GGA approximation with the TPSSh exchange-correlation functional. Input geometries were generated from the corresponding crystallographic data. In these calculations we used the standard Ahlrichs' valence triple-ξ including polarization functions (TZVP). No symmetry constraints have been imposed during the optimizations. In the case of NiII complexes the highest spin state was considered as the ground state (triplet). Since these calculations performed on the [Ni(tmdta)]2- complex used an unrestricted model, spin contamination was assessed by a comparison of the expected difference between S(S + 1) for the assigned spin state (S(S + 1) = 2.0 for the mononuclear NiII complexes investigated here) and the actual value of ⟨S 2⟩. The results obtained indicate that spin contamination is negligible for systems investigated in this work [⟨S 2⟩ - S(S + 1) ~ 0.0030]. The stationary points found on  potential energy surfaces as a result of geometry optimizations were tested to represent energy minima rather than saddle points via frequency analysis. Default values for the integration grid (75 radial shells and 302 angular points) and the SCF energy convergence criteria (10-8) were used in all calculations. The interconversions between the twist-boat (tb) and half-chair (hc) forms and the exchange between in-plane and out-of-plane glycinate rings of [Ni(tmdta)]2- were investigated by means of the synchronous transit-guided quasi-Newton method. The nature of the saddle points (one imaginary frequency) was characterized by frequency analysis. The relative free energies of the two energy minima and the free energy barrier for their interconversion were calculated in aqueous solution at the TPSSh/TZVP level, and they include non-potential-energy contributions (zero-point energies and thermal terms) obtained through frequency analysis.

elements.content: Isotropic 1H and 13C HFCCs of the hc and tb forms of [Ni(tmdta)]2– were calculated in aqueous solution with unrestricted DFT methods by employing the TPSSh functional and the TZVP basis set for Ni. In all DFT investigations of HFCCs specifically developed basis sets with extra flexibility in the core region should be employed. Thus, for the description of C, H, N, and O we used the EPR-III basis sets of Barone, which is a triple-ζ basis set including diffuse functions, double d polarizations, and a single set of f-polarization functions, together with an improved s-part to better describe the nuclear region. The isotropic Fermi contact contribution (A iso) of the hyperfine coupling tensor for a nucleus N is given by A iso ( N ) = 4 π 3 S μ B μ N g e g N ρ α − β ( R N ) where μB and μe are the nuclear and Bohr magnetons, respectively, g N and g e are nuclear and free-electron g values, S is the total spin of the system, and ρα–β represents the difference between majority spin (α) and minority spin (β) densities.

In all DFT investigations of HFCCs specifically developed basis sets with extra flexibility in the core region should be employed. Thus, for the description of C, H, N, and O we used the EPR-III basis sets of Barone, which is a triple-ζ basis set including diffuse functions, double d polarizations, and a single set of f-polarization functions, together with an improved s-part to better describe the nuclear region. The isotropic Fermi contact contribution (A iso) of the hyperfine coupling tensor for a nucleus N is given by  1    A   iso    ( N )  =   4 π   3 S     μ   B     μ   N     g   e     g   N     ρ   α - β    (   R   N   )   where μB and μe are the nuclear and Bohr magnetons, respectively, g N and g e are nuclear and free-electron g values, S is the total spin of the system, and ρα-β represents the difference between majority spin (α) and minority spin (β) densities.

elements.content: The NMR shift observed for a given nucleus i of a paramagnetic metal ion j (δ ij exp) is the result of both paramagnetic (δ ij para) and diamagnetic (δ ij dia) contributions δ i j exp = δ i j para + δ i j dia

elements.content: The paramagnetic contribution to the observed chemical shifts is the result of both contact and pseudocontact contributions. However, 13C NMR paramagnetic shifts of Ni2+ complexes are expected to be largely contact in origin, although nuclei residing far away from the paramagnetic center in terms of number of bonds might have sizable pseudocontact contributions. The contact contribution may be approximated by the following equation δ i j con = g e μ B S ( S + 1 ) 3 γ I k B T A ℏ × 10 6 = F A ℏ where A/ℏ is the scalar hyperfine coupling constant, S is the total electron spin of the system, g e is the free electron g value, μB is the electron Bohr magneton, γI is the nuclear magnetogyric ratio, and T is the temperature. In eq A/ℏ is expressed in rad·s–1 and therefore equals 2π·A iso as defined in eq .

The contact contribution may be approximated by the following equation 3    δ   i j   con   =     g   e     μ   B   S  ( S + 1 )    3   γ   I     k   B   T     A   ℏ   ×   10   6   = F   A   ℏ    where A/ℏ is the scalar hyperfine coupling constant, S is the total electron spin of the system, g e is the free electron g value, μB is the electron Bohr magneton, γI is the nuclear magnetogyric ratio, and T is the temperature. In eq  A/ℏ is expressed in rad⋅s-1 and therefore equals 2π⋅A iso as defined in eq .

elements.content: The NMR shielding tensors of the [Zn(tmdta)]2– system were computed in aqueous solution at the TPSSh/TZVP level using the GIAO method. For chemical shift calculation purposes, NMR shielding tensors of TMS were calculated at the same computational level. IR spectra were simulated from the calculated harmonic frequencies and IR intensities obtained through second derivatives, with the aid of the GaussView program. A half width at half height of 4 cm–1 was applied. Frequencies used to obtain the simulated spectra were unscaled. Raman spectra were simulated in a similar way from the harmonic frequencies and Raman intensities calculated from molecular polarizabilities. A half width at half height of 8 cm–1 and a scaling factor of 1.05 were used.

For chemical shift calculation purposes, NMR shielding tensors of TMS were calculated at the same computational level. IR spectra were simulated from the calculated harmonic frequencies and IR intensities obtained through second derivatives, with the aid of the GaussView program. A half width at half height of 4 cm-1 was applied. Frequencies used to obtain the simulated spectra were unscaled. Raman spectra were simulated in a similar way from the harmonic frequencies and Raman intensities calculated from molecular polarizabilities. A half width at half height of 8 cm-1 and a scaling factor of 1.05 were used.

elements.content: Throughout this work solvent effects were included using the polarizable continuum model (PCM), in which the solute cavity is built as an envelope of spheres centered on atoms or atomic groups with appropriate radii. In particular, we used the integral equation formalism (IEFPCM) variant as implemented in Gaussian 09.

In particular, we used the integral equation formalism (IEFPCM) variant as implemented in Gaussian 09.

elements.content: The structure of 1a (cf. Figure a; for asymmetric unit cf. Figure S1a, ) contains two crystallographically independent Li+ tetraheda, a six-coordinate [Ni(tmdta)]2– complex anion, and five crystal water molecules, where three are Li bound and two are fixed only by H bonds. Basic crystallographic features for structures 1a in comparison to 1b and 2a are collected in Table S1 ().
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structural Features of 1a, 1b, and 2a compared with 2b 

The structure of 1a (cf. Figure a; for asymmetric unit cf. Figure S1a, ) contains two crystallographically independent Li+ tetraheda, a six-coordinate [Ni(tmdta)]2- complex anion, and five crystal water molecules, where three are Li bound and two are fixed only by H bonds. Basic crystallographic features for structures 1a in comparison to 1b and 2a are collected in Table S1 ().

elements.content: The NiIIN2O4 core comprises a severely distorted octahedron (similar to the one in structure 1b, see below) when compared with those found in structures 2a and 2b. This becomes evident by comparison of the deviation of the four in-plane L–Ni–L′ angles from the ideal value of 90°. The sums of the individual deviations are 43.4° (1a), 48.7° (1b), 32.1° (2a), and 30.8° (2b). This is a consequence of the different diamine chelate ring conformations: half-chair in 1a and 1b vs twist-boat in 2a and 2b (cf. Figure d).The peculiarity of the salt structure 1a is that crystallization takes place in the homochiral space group P21, which has already been observed for the isostructural salt Li2[Co(tmdta)]·5H2O. As described there, the main reason for chiral discrimination in the course of crystallization is the special type of rigidification of the chelate matrix by the peculiar lithium dimer encountered in both isostructural complex salts.

This becomes evident by comparison of the deviation of the four in-plane L-Ni-L' angles from the ideal value of 90°. The sums of the individual deviations are 43.4° (1a), 48.7° (1b), 32.1° (2a), and 30.8° (2b). This is a consequence of the different diamine chelate ring conformations: half-chair in 1a and 1b vs twist-boat in 2a and 2b (cf. Figure d).The peculiarity of the salt structure 1a is that crystallization takes place in the homochiral space group P21, which has already been observed for the isostructural salt Li2[Co(tmdta)]⋅5H2O. As described there, the main reason for chiral discrimination in the course of crystallization is the special type of rigidification of the chelate matrix by the peculiar lithium dimer encountered in both isostructural complex salts.

elements.content: The structure of 1b (cf. Figure b; for asymmetric unit cf. Figure S1b, ) consists of two {C(NH2)3}+ cations, a [Ni(tmdta)]2– unit, and 6 water molecules of crystallization. As mentioned above, the deviation from octahedral symmetry is more pronounced in 1b.
elements.clean_text: The structure of 1b (cf. Figure b; for asymmetric unit cf. Figure S1b, ) consists of two {C(NH2)3}+ cations, a [Ni(tmdta)]2- unit, and 6 water molecules of crystallization. As mentioned above, the deviation from octahedral symmetry is more pronounced in 1b.

elements.content: There are two octahedral NiII units ([Ni(tmdta)]2– and [Ni(H2O)6]2+) and two waters of crystallization in the structure of 2a (cf. Figure c; asymmetric unit cf. Figure S1c, ). As required by crystallographic symmetry of the orthorhombic space group Pnna, a C 2 axis (highest symmetry element in this structure) passes through the Ni2 center and the central carbon (C2) of the T ring. Atoms Ni2 and C2 of the T ring are on special positions 4d of space group Pnna. Thus, the complex has C 2 symmetry. Both in-plane (G) glycinate rings are symmetry equivalent, as well as both out-of-plane (R) glycinate rings. The puckering extent of the glycinate rings is much more pronounced for G than for R rings, in line with the work of Hoard et al., who also introduced the G, R notation.

As required by crystallographic symmetry of the orthorhombic space group Pnna, a C 2 axis (highest symmetry element in this structure) passes through the Ni2 center and the central carbon (C2) of the T ring. Atoms Ni2 and C2 of the T ring are on special positions 4d of space group Pnna. Thus, the complex has C 2 symmetry. Both in-plane (G) glycinate rings are symmetry equivalent, as well as both out-of-plane (R) glycinate rings. The puckering extent of the glycinate rings is much more pronounced for G than for R rings, in line with the work of Hoard  et al., who also introduced the G, R notation.

elements.content: Important bond lengths and angles of the structures determined here (1a, 1b, and 2a) are compared with data of 2b in Table . The bond lengths and angles in Table are assigned according to the donor atom pattern shown in Scheme . Both hc structures show Ni–N bond distances (Ni–N)av,hc = 2.10(2) Å, somewhat longer than those found in the tb structures (Ni–N)av,tb = 2.076(4) Å. This is a consequence of different degrees of strain depending upon if the NiII center is either wrapped by tmdta in the hc or the tb coordination mode. Clearly, Ni–N bonding is less strained in the tb structures.

elements.clean_text: 2  Indication of Donor Atoms and Bond Angles Used in Current Work

elements.content: The (Ni–OG)av distances in hc structures 1a (2.08(4) Å) and 1b (2.095(5) Å) are slightly longer than the corresponding (Ni–OR)av bonds (2.079(1) Å for 1a and 2.076(8) Å for 1b). This is different in the case of tb structures 2a and 2b where the Ni–OG bond lengths are in both cases (Ni–OG = 2.0241(12) Å for 2a and 2.027(5) Å for 2b) significantly shorter than Ni–OR distances (Ni–OR = 2.0763(12) Å for 2a and 2.078(5) Å for 2b). The initial assumption that the longer Ni–OR distances are caused by packing effects had to be discarded because the tb structure obtained by DFT geometry optimization in aqueous solution (TPSSh/TZVP) shows the same pattern of (Ni–OG) vs (Ni–OR) bond length difference, i.e., the in-plane Ni–OG bond distances are substantially shorter than out-of-plane Ni–OR bonds. This is in contrast to the bond length patterns of tb MIII–tmdta structures observed in the isostructural salts Na[M(tmdta)]·3H2O including K[Co(tmdta)]·2H2O, which are analyzed in Figure using Shannon plots. In a Shannon plot, M–L distances from crystal structure analysis are related to hypothetical bond lengths constructed from the sum of the Shannon radii (Shannon radius = IR) between the appropriate metal ion M and the ligand donor atom L ((M–L)Shannon = IR(M n+) + IR(L)). Thus, Δ = {(M–L)Shannon – (M–L)exp} values have a positive sign if (M–L)exp is shorter than (M–L)Shannon, while a negative sign results if (M–L)exp is longer than (M–L)Shannon.

This is different in the case of tb structures 2a and 2b where the Ni-OG bond lengths are in both cases (Ni-OG = 2.0241(12) Å for 2a and 2.027(5) Å for 2b) significantly shorter than Ni-OR distances (Ni-OR = 2.0763(12) Å for 2a and 2.078(5) Å for 2b). The initial assumption that the longer Ni-OR distances are caused by packing effects had to be discarded because the tb structure obtained by DFT geometry optimization in aqueous solution (TPSSh/TZVP) shows the same pattern of (Ni-OG) vs (Ni-OR) bond length difference, i.e., the in-plane Ni-OG bond distances are substantially shorter than out-of-plane Ni-OR bonds. This is in contrast to the bond length patterns of tb MIII-tmdta structures observed in the isostructural salts Na[M(tmdta)]⋅3H2O including K[Co(tmdta)]⋅2H2O, which are analyzed in Figure  using Shannon plots. In a Shannon plot, M-L distances from crystal structure analysis are related to hypothetical bond lengths constructed from the sum of the Shannon radii (Shannon radius = IR) between the appropriate metal ion M and the ligand donor atom L ((M-L)Shannon = IR(M n+) + IR(L)). Thus, Δ = {(M-L)Shannon - (M-L)exp} values have a positive sign if (M-L)exp is shorter than (M-L)Shannon, while a negative sign results if (M-L)exp is longer than (M-L)Shannon.

elements.content: As shown in Figure a, the M–OR distances are always shorter than M–OG for M = CoIII (d6 LS), CrIII (d3), VIII (d2), and RhIII (d6 LS) but the rule is broken in the case of FeIII (d5 HS), where suddenly Fe–OR is somewhat longer than Fe–OG. There seems to be a simple explanation for this behavior: The main interaction responsible for binding of the carboxylate oxygen of tmdta is the result of a σ bonding due to donation of electron density from O p orbitals into the eg orbitals (d x 2–y 2 , d z 2 ) of the metal center. The eg sublevel is empty in the case of d6 LS, d3 HS, and d2 HS configurations. In these cases, the better spatial overlap between the O p orbitals and the d z 2 acceptor orbital at the metal site (along the z axis) leads to shorter M–OR and longer M–OG bonds. As soon as the eg orbitals are filled with electrons as in the case of d5 HS (FeIII), electrostatic repulsion between O p orbitals and d z 2 acceptor orbitals leads to longer M–OR and shorter M–OG distances. The longer M–OG bonds are presumably also related to the weaker overlap between O p orbitals and d x 2–y 2 orbital on the metal site caused by the always greater puckering of G- vs R-glycinate rings.

There seems to be a simple explanation for this behavior: The main interaction responsible for binding of the carboxylate oxygen of tmdta is the result of a σ bonding due to donation of electron density from O p orbitals into the eg orbitals (d x 2-y 2 , d z 2 ) of the metal center. The eg sublevel is empty in the case of d6 LS, d3 HS, and d2 HS configurations. In these cases, the better spatial overlap between the O p orbitals and the d z 2  acceptor orbital at the metal site (along the z axis) leads to shorter M-OR and longer M-OG bonds. As soon as the eg orbitals are filled with electrons as in the case of d5 HS (FeIII), electrostatic repulsion between O p orbitals and d z 2  acceptor orbitals leads to longer M-OR and shorter M-OG distances. The longer M-OG bonds are presumably also related to the weaker overlap between O p orbitals and d x 2-y 2  orbital on the metal site caused by the always greater puckering of G- vs R-glycinate rings.

elements.content: M–L bond length patterns in the {Mg(H2O)6}[MII(tmdta)]·2H2O tb structures with M= Co (d7 HS), Ni (d8 HS), Cu (d9), and Zn (d10) are compared in Figure b. Understanding of these patterns can be reached in a similar way as shown above for the MIII structures. All these metal ions have partially (CoII, NiII, CuII) or fully (ZnII) occupied eg orbitals; thus, the greater electrostatic repulsion along the z axis leads to longer M–OR and shorter M–OG bonds as shown in Figure b.

All these metal ions have partially (CoII, NiII, CuII) or fully (ZnII) occupied eg orbitals; thus, the greater electrostatic repulsion along the z axis leads to longer M-OR and shorter M-OG bonds as shown in Figure b.

elements.content: As described above, there is no substantial difference between the Ni–OG and the Ni–OR distances in the case of the both hc structures 1a and 1b. However, there are important differences between hc structures 1a and 1b and tb structures 2a and 2b in terms of their deviation from regular O h symmetry. It has already been mentioned above that the in-plane L–Ni–L′ angles are much more away from the ideal value of 90° for the hc form as compared to the tb one. Another measure of deviation from the regular octahedral symmetry is delivered by trigonal twist angles ϕ, where ϕ = 60° for an ideal octahedron and ϕ = 0° for an ideal trigonal prism. The definition of the three ϕ angles we used to obtain information concerning the deviation from strictly octahedral symmetry of the cis-NiN2O4 cores of tb and hc salts of [Ni(tmdta)]2– is shown in Scheme . X1 and X2 are the centroids (geometric centers) of the triangles confined by N1, OG1, OR1 and N2, OG2, OR2. The ϕ1, ϕ2, and ϕ3 values for structures 1a, 1b, 2a, and 2b are collected in Table . These data show unambiguously that there is some influence leading to irregular distortion in the hc structures away from O h symmetry, while both tb structures show a lesser degree of distortion. Also, the distortion is more pronounced in the case of the structure 1b relative to 1a. A detailed analysis of the structural data (see ) shows that Dunitz plots are a convenient and an effective tool to judge puckering in five-membered and six-membered chelate ring. These plots are based on the empirical finding by J. D. Dunitz that in five- and six-membered rings a linear relationship exists between the sum of the 5 intraring valence angles Σωring and the squared sum of the 5 intraring torsion angles Στ2 ring. The linear regression line through data in Figure reveals the correctness of the data because if Σωring ≈ Στ2 ring is strictly valid the plot should intersect the ordinate at Σωring = 540°, the value for the completely planar ring. The plot also shows that the chelate ring R1 is considerably more puckered than R2. The puckering patterns of the glycinate chelate rings in the tb structures are more even than that shown in Figure (cf. Figure S6, ) and resemble the patterns found in R and G rings of [Ni(edta)]2– structures with rather flat R rings and G rings that are less puckered than those in the hc structures. A check of the structural distortions in the related tmdta complex structures Li[Fe(tmdta)]·3H2O and Li2[Co(tmdta)]·5H2O reveals puckering patterns roughly identical to that found in 1a. A detailed analysis of the solid state and DFT geometries shows that intramolecular H···H repulsion between the various CH2 groups are the main cause for the more important puckering of the glycinate chelate rings in the hc structures, which in turn results in a more pronounced distortion of the coordination environment with respect to the regular octahedral coordination (see for details).

Solution Structure and Dynamics

13C NMR spectra of [Ni(tmdta)]2– (Figure ) were recorded in D2O solution at different temperatures. Spectra recorded in the temperature range 293–353 K show six resonances whose chemical shifts present a linear dependence with the reciprocal Kelvin temperature (Figure S8, ), which indicates that the contact contribution dominates the Ni2+-induced paramagnetic shifts. Assignment of the 13C NMR signals (Table ) was achieved by comparison with the shifts reported for [Ni(edta)]2– and [Ni(cydta)]2–  and confirmed by our DFT calculations described below. 13C NMR signals due to the methylenic carbon nuclei of the glycinate groups (R CH2COO– and G CH2COO–), observed at −281.5 and −424.7 ppm at 293 K, gradually broaden upon increasing temperature, and finally, they achieve coalescence at 373 K. A similar effect is observed for the two signals of the carbon nuclei of carbonyl groups, which are observed at 25.3 and −84.9 ppm at 293 K. This behavior reflects a dynamic exchange process that exchanges the positions of the out-of-plane (R) and in-plane (G) glycinate groups. From the chemical shift difference of the signals due to the methylene carbon nuclei and the coalescence temperature of 373 K we estimate an activation free energy for this dynamic process of 64.2 kJ mol–1, which corresponds to a rate k c = 8.2 × 103 s–1 at this temperature. This rate is 2 orders of magnitude lower than that determined for the exchange of the coordinated water molecule in [Ni(tmdta)(H2O)]2–, which represents a very small fraction of the complex present in solution (f = 0.028). This implies that the two processes occur in completely different time scales, with many water exchange events taking place in between two interconversions of the R and G glycinate groups.

Solution Structure and Dynamics

 13C NMR spectra of [Ni(tmdta)]2- (Figure ) were recorded in D2O solution at different temperatures. Spectra recorded in the temperature range 293-353 K show six resonances whose chemical shifts present a linear dependence with the reciprocal Kelvin temperature (Figure S8, ), which indicates that the contact contribution dominates the Ni2+-induced paramagnetic shifts. Assignment of the 13C NMR signals (Table ) was achieved by comparison with the shifts reported for [Ni(edta)]2- and [Ni(cydta)]2-                 and confirmed by our DFT calculations described below.  13C NMR signals due to the methylenic carbon nuclei of the glycinate groups (R CH2COO- and G CH2COO-), observed at -281.5 and -424.7 ppm at 293 K, gradually broaden upon increasing  temperature, and finally, they achieve coalescence at 373 K. A similar effect is observed for the two signals of the carbon nuclei of carbonyl groups, which are observed at 25.3 and -84.9 ppm at 293 K. This behavior reflects a dynamic exchange process that exchanges the positions of the out-of-plane (R) and in-plane (G) glycinate groups. From the chemical shift difference of the signals due to the methylene carbon nuclei and the coalescence temperature of 373 K we estimate an activation free energy for this dynamic process of 64.2 kJ mol-1, which corresponds to a rate k c = 8.2 × 103 s-1 at this temperature. This rate is 2 orders of magnitude lower than that determined for the exchange of the coordinated water molecule in [Ni(tmdta)(H2O)]2-, which represents a very small fraction of the complex present in solution (f = 0.028). This implies that the two processes occur in completely different time scales, with many water exchange events taking place in between two interconversions of the R and G glycinate groups.

elements.content: Aiming to obtain information on the structure in solution of the [Ni(tmdta)]2– complex we performed density functional theory (DFT) calculations at the TPSSh/TZVP level. In these calculations we have taken into account solvent effects (water) using a polarizable continuum model (PCM). Geometry optimizations provided two energy minima corresponding to the tb and hc forms of the complex. The agreement between the DFT-optimized structures and those observed in the solid state is excellent (Table , see also Figures S9 and S11, ).

Geometry optimizations provided two energy minima corresponding to the tb and hc forms of the complex. The agreement between the DFT-optimized structures and those observed in the solid state is excellent (Table , see also Figures S9 and S11, ).

The calculated relative free energies of the tb and hc conformers is rather small, favoring the tb form over the hc one by only 0.96 kJ mol–1. This free energy difference provides an equilibrium constant at 298 K K = x hc/ x tb = 0.68 using ΔG = −RT ln K, which corresponds to a molar fraction of hc conformer x hc = 0.40 and thus a 2:3 (hc:tb) ratio of the two conformers in aqueous solution at 298 K. The interconversion between the tb and the hc conformers requires a change in the conformation of the six-membered chelate ring formed upon coordination of the trimethylenediamine moiety. The tb conformer is characterized by two identical CH2(α)–CH2(β)–CH2(α)–N dihedral angles of −37.3° due to the C 2 molecular symmetry, while in the hc form these dihedral angles amount to 66.7° and −86.8°. The transition state responsible for the interconversion between the two forms is characterized by intermediate values of these angles (26.6° and −78.79°) with one of the CH2(β)–CH2(α) units in a nearly eclipsed conformation (Figure S9, ). According to our calculations the activation free energy for tb ⇌ hc interconversion is 13.5 kJ mol–1.

elements.content: This energy barrier is very low, and significantly higher activation energies were estimated for the inversion of five-membered chelate rings in Ni2+ complexes with ethylenediamine (20–29 kJ·mol–1) and N,N,N′,N′-tetramethylenediamine (32 kJ·mol–1). Thus, the interconversion of the tb and hc conformers present in solution is expected to be fast in the NMR time scale, and consequently, NMR signals showing this interconversion (i.e., 13C shifts of CH2(α) and CH2(β)) could not be resolved, even with a 600 MHz NMR instrument. As a consequence, the 13C NMR shifts observed in D2O solutions correspond to weighted averages of the chemical shifts of the tb and hc conformers.

elements.content: The low energy barrier obtained from DFT calculations for the tb → hc interconversion indicates that the dynamic process observed in the 13C NMR spectra is related to a different exchange event. Most likely this is related to an intramolecular exchange process leading to a Δ ⇌ Λ enantiomerization, which involves rotation of the acetate groups of the ligand that exchanges the in-plane and out-of-plane carboxylate units. This process might proceed intramolecularly following a concerted rotation of the four acetate groups of the ligand or it may be assisted by solvent exchange processes, as proposed for [Al(edta)]−. DFT calculations were used to model the intramolecular Δ ⇌ Λ interconversion process. The TS responsible for the interconversion between the Δ and the Λ forms presents a trigonal prismatic coordination around the NiII ion with a very long Ni–N distance of 2.71 Å (Figure S9 and Table S3, ). The free energy of activation calculated for this process (79.4 kJ mol–1) is significantly higher than the one obtained from analysis of the 13C NMR data (64.2 kJ mol–1), which suggests that the Δ ⇌ Λ interconversion in [Ni(tmdta)]2– is assisted by the coordination of a water molecule, either with opening of a glycinate chelate ring or through a seven-coordinate intermediate.

elements.content: The 13C NMR chemical shifts of [Ni(tmdta)]2– are the result of both diamagnetic and paramagnetic contributions. The diamagnetic contribution in the case of paramagnetic lanthanide (Ln3+) complexes is often estimated from the chemical shifts observed for diamagnetic analogues such as La3+ or Lu3+ complexes. The trivalent Ln3+ ions represent a group of metal ions that are very similar in terms of their coordination chemistry, and therefore, this assumption is clearly justified. In the case of Ni2+ complexes diamagnetic shifts could be estimated from the chemical shifts of the free ligand, but this would neglect the contribution to the diamagnetic shifts caused by conformational changes, inductive effects, and direct field effects related to complexation. Alternatively, the diamagnetic shifts could be estimated from the 13C NMR shifts observed for [Zn(tmdta)]2–, assuming that the Ni2+ and Zn2+ complexes adopt similar structures. The X-ray structures published for different salts of the [Zn(tmdta)]2– complex indeed show that the Ni2+ and Zn2+ complexes of tmdta have very similar structures. The Zn2+ complex was shown to adopt a tb conformation in the solid state. Thus, we performed geometry optimizations of both the tb and hc conformers of [Zn(tmdta)]2– at the TPSSh/TZVP level and calculated the 13C NMR shifts of each conformer using the GIAO method (Table ). This method has been shown to provide theoretical 13C NMR shifts in good agreement with the experimental values for different Zn2+ complexes. The 13C NMR spectrum of [Zn(tmdta)]2– has been reported previously but showed averaged signals for the methylene carbon of the exchanging in-plane and out-of-plane acetate groups (64.5 ppm) and a single averaged carboxylate resonance (181.3 ppm). Our results (Table ) show that the tb and hc forms present very similar chemical shifts, the larger chemical shift differences being predicted for the 13C NMR signals of the α CH2 and R CH2COO– nuclei (7.5 and 6.0 ppm, respectively).

13C NMR shifts of [Zn(tmdta)]2– obtained with the GIAO method.

In recent works it has been demonstrated that DFT calculations provide 1H and 17O hyperfine coupling constants of water molecules directly coordinated to Mn2+ and Gd3+ in very good agreement with the experimental data. In the case of Gd3+ complexes calculation of 1H A iso values also allowed us to calculate contact shifts for the Tb3+ analogues. Analogous calculations performed on the tb and hc conformers of [Ni(tmdta)]2– provided the A iso values given in Table . The A iso values obtained for the β CH2 and R COO– nuclei of the two conformers differ significantly, and therefore, the 13C NMR signals of these nuclei encode structural information that can be used to determine the relative populations of the conformers in solution. The calculated hyperfine coupling constants are all negative, except those corresponding to the β CH2 nucleus, which are positive. The presence of alternate spin density (shift) signs along the pathway of the bonded atoms radiating out from the paramagnetic atom is a characteristic pattern that indicates that the contact shifts are dominated by spin polarization effects rather than spin delocalization. Spin polarization is the result of an effective attraction of unpaired electrons to the nearby ones of the same spin. The β carbon of the propyl unit is three bonds away from the Ni2+ ion, while the remaining carbon nuclei of the ligand backbone are situated two bonds away from the paramagnetic center. Thus, the 13C NMR shifts of [Ni(tmdta)]2– appear to be dominated by spin-polarization effects. This is in line with the signs of the hyperfine coupling constants determined experimentally for α and β carbon nuclei of simple amino acids in the presence of Ni2+.

elements.content: The calculated A iso values calculated for the tb and hc conformers of [Ni(tmdta)]2– were used to assess the relative abundance of these species in solution. For this purpose, we performed a least-squares fit that minimizes the difference between the experimental and calculated δiNi exp values as given by the following expression δ i Ni = F [ x t b A i , t b iso + ( 1 − x t b ) A i , h c iso ] + x t b δ i Zn , t b calcd + x t b δ i Zn , h c calcd where the fitting parameters are the molar fraction of tb isomer, x tb, and the proportionality constant F (eq ). In this equation A i,tb iso represents the calculated hyperfine coupling constant of a nucleus i of the tb conformer (in MHz), and δ iZn,tb calcd is the chemical shift of nucleus i obtained for the tb isomer of [Zn(tmdta)]2– with GIAO calculations. The best fit of the data provided the calculated shifts reported in Table , with x tb = 0.60 ± 0.14 and F = 286.0 ± 10.0. The agreement between the experimental and calculated 13C NMR shifts is quite good, with an agreement factor AF i = 0.090. Furthermore, the value of F obtained from the fit is in excellent agreement with the theoretical value obtained with eq at 293 K (285.9). In addition, the molar fraction of tb conformer is in good agreement with the IR and Raman studies described below. Therefore, we conclude that (i) our DFT calculations provide accurate 13C hyperfine coupling constants, (ii) the paramagnetic shifts of [Ni(tmdta)]2– are largely dominated by the contact contribution, and (iii) our combined NMR and DFT approach allows for an accurate determination of the relative populations of tb and hc conformers in aqueous solution.

elements.content: IR spectra of a 0.6 M aqueous solution of Li2[Ni(tmdta)] 1a could be obtained in the range 1000–1250 cm–1 (Figure ). The spectrum is compared with those recorded in the solid state for the Li2[Ni(tmdta)] and Mg[Ni(tmdta)] salts, which provide hc and tb conformations, respectively (see above). The spectrum of the Li+ salt presents two features at 1008 and 1020 cm–1, assigned to rocking vibrations of the methylene groups, ρ(CH2). The spectrum of the Mg2+ salt, which adopts a tb conformation, shows the band due to the ρ(CH2) vibration at 1046 cm–1, quite well separated from those observed for the Li+ salt. Thus, these bands can provide information on the relative populations of the tb and hc conformers present in solution. The IR spectrum obtained for the Li+ salt in aqueous solution shows bands at 1010, 1021, and 1041 cm–1 that clearly identify the presence of both conformers in solution with significant populations.

Vibrational Spectroscopy

IR spectra of a 0.6 M aqueous solution of Li2[Ni(tmdta)] 1a could be obtained in the range 1000-1250 cm-1 (Figure ). The spectrum is compared with those recorded in the solid state for the Li2[Ni(tmdta)] and Mg[Ni(tmdta)] salts, which provide hc and tb conformations, respectively (see above). The spectrum of the Li+ salt presents two features at 1008 and 1020 cm-1, assigned to rocking vibrations of the methylene groups, ρ(CH2). The spectrum of the Mg2+ salt, which adopts a tb conformation, shows the band due to the ρ(CH2) vibration at 1046 cm-1, quite well separated from those observed for the Li+ salt. Thus, these bands can provide information on the relative populations of the tb and hc conformers present in solution. The IR spectrum obtained for the Li+ salt in aqueous solution shows bands at 1010, 1021, and 1041 cm-1 that clearly identify the presence of both conformers in solution with significant populations.

elements.content: The geometries of the tb and hc conformers of [Ni(tmdta)]2– optimized at the TPSSh/TZVP level were used to calculate the corresponding vibrational wavenumbers within the harmonic approach. Calculated spectra are compared with the spectrum recorded in aqueous solution in Figure , while the positions of the calculated bands are compared to the experimental data of the Li+ and Mg2+ salts in Table . Our calculations provide unscaled vibrational frequencies in excellent agreement with those observed in the solid state. A comparison of the calculated spectra with the experimental spectrum obtained in solution clearly confirms that the two conformers have sizable populations in water.

In order to obtain quantitative information on the relative abundance of the tb and hc forms in aqueous solution, we performed simulations of the experimental solution spectrum using linear combinations of the spectra calculated for the two conformers. A similar approach has been shown to allow determining accurately the tb/hc ratio using DFT-calculated Raman spectra. The experimental spectrum recorded in aqueous solution could be accurately simulated using a hc:tb ratio of 2:3 (Figure ). The bands observed at 1010 and 1021 cm–1 in the solution spectrum arise from rocking vibrations of the methylene groups [ρ(CH2)] of the hc conformer, while the band at 1041 cm–1 is associated with the same vibrational mode of the tb form. The spectral region 1060–1200 cm–1 presents mixtures of ν(C–C) and ν(N–C) stretching modes of the two conformers.

elements.content: The Raman spectrum of the Li+ salt of [Ni(tmdta)]2– was obtained in aqueous solution in the region 300–600 cm–1. As noticed before, the Fe–O and Fe–N stretching modes and skeletal vibrations of the coordination polyhedron are observed in this region. The spectrum recorded in solution (Figure ) is dominated by two bands at 438 and 510 cm–1 and presents bands of lower intensity at 468, 403, and 360 cm–1. A comparison of the calculated Raman spectra with the spectrum measured in aqueous solution shows that the main features of the latter are likely to have significant contributions of the two conformers. The theoretical spectrum simulated from the calculated Raman spectra and intensities using a hc:tb ratio of 2:3 present excellent agreement with the experimental spectrum, which confirms the predictions made on the basis of the IR spectra. Calculated Raman peaks and intensities for the two isomers and their assignments are compiled in Table . Analysis of the calculated Raman spectra shows that this region has a contribution of a large number of vibrational modes, including out of plane deformations of the carboxylate groups [π(CO)], rocking vibrations of the methylene groups [ρ(CH2)], sometimes coupled to ν(Ni–N) stretching vibrations, and deformations of the six-membered chelate ring formed upon coordination of the propylenediamine unit.

As shown in Figure (for band positions see Table ), the solid state spectra of both hc salts 1a and 1b differ considerably from that of tb salt 2b. While the relative intensities of the transitions at higher energies (I 3A2g → 3T1g ( P ), II 3A2g → 3T1g ( F )) are roughly the same for the tb and hc isomers, the large intensity difference of band IV (3A2g → 3T2g( F ) transition) for hc and tb isomers (hc intensity is only one-half the tb one at position of this band) is unexpected and there is no example in the current literature for any similar observation. We assume that lowering in the symmetry described in the solid structures of 1a and 1b (described in the structure section above) is responsible for the low intensity of the 10 Dq band in the hc spectra.

Electronic Spectra of [Ni(tmdta)]2- Salts in the Solid State and in Aqueous Solution

As shown in Figure  (for band positions see Table ), the solid state spectra of  both hc salts 1a and 1b differ considerably from that of tb salt 2b. While the relative intensities of the transitions at higher energies (I 3A2g → 3T1g ( P ), II 3A2g → 3T1g ( F )) are roughly the same for the tb and hc isomers, the large intensity difference of band IV (3A2g → 3T2g( F ) transition) for hc and tb isomers (hc intensity is only one-half the tb one at position of this band) is unexpected and there is no example in the current literature for any similar observation. We assume that lowering in the symmetry described in the solid structures of 1a and 1b (described in the structure section above) is responsible for the low intensity of the 10 Dq band in the hc spectra.

Interesting is the comparison shown in Figure b where the solid state spectra of 1a and 2b are compared with the unique solution spectrum of [Ni(tmdta)]2– (the solution spectrum is not dependent upon whether tb or hc is dissolved). As observed before, the intensity of the 10 Dq band in the case of the solution spectrum is reflecting the presence of a tb/hc equilibrium mixture in aqueous solutions.

elements.content: In previous works we have shown that pH-dependent spectrophotometric titration experiments can be applied to estimate various types of equilibrium constants with the aid of the SPECFIT software developed by Zuberbühler et al. Titration of water-soluble metal chelate complexes with acid accompanied by pH lowering delivers usually equilibrium constants for complex formation and stepwise protonation constants of appropriate complexes. The conditional equilibrium expressions for the relevant processes valid for NiII–tmdta are given in eqs and , while the mass balance equations required for quantitative analysis are formulated in eqs and . The spectrum of the neutral solution containing [NiII(tmdta)]2– is gradually changed upon addition of HClO4conc in small aliquots as shown in Figure a. A fit to the spectra shown in Figure a applying SPECFIT and a three-component model (species [NiII(tmdta)]2–, [NiII(Htmdta)(H2O)]−, and [NiII(H2O)6]2+) delivers the results shown in Figure b and c and Table . The data reported in Table reveals a good agreement between our constants and those given in the literature, in particular considering that the literature values were determined at an ionic strength I = 0.1 M (K+ containing supporting electrolyte, 25 °C) while our data were measured at an ionic strength of I = 1.0 M NaClO4, 25 °C. [ Ni II ( tmdta ) ] 2 − + H 3 O + ⇄ 1 / K a 1 H [ Ni II ( Htmdta ) ( H 2 O ) ] − [ Ni II ( Htmdta ) ( H 2 O ) ] − + 5 H 3 O + ⇄ [ Ni II ( H 2 O ) 6 ] 2 + + H 6 tmdta 2 + [ Ni ( H 2 O ) 6 ] 2 + + Htmdta 3 − ⇄ log ⁡ β 1 1 1 [ Ni II ( Htmdta ) ( H 2 O ) ] − [ Ni ( H 2 O ) 6 ] 2 + + tmdta 4 − ⇄ log ⁡ β 1 1 0 [ Ni II ( tmdta ) ] 2 − Our pK a1H for the protonation of [NiII(tmdta)]2– (reverse process of reaction ) is considerably lower than the one originally estimated by Anderegg. In the latter work, equilibrium data were measured by pH potentiometry at 20 °C, I = 0.1 M (KNO3). The authors state that the pK a1H value they evaluated can contain large errors. The pK a1H = 2.69 that we evaluated for NiII–edta is in very good agreement with one given by Higginson (pK a1H = 2.63), who used spectrophotometric titrations for his measurements and solution conditions identical with ours (I = 1.0 M NaClO4, 25 °C). This shows that our approach is suitable to gain reliable data. A surprising feature of these equilibrium constants that needs explanation is the gap between pK a1H = 0.78 for NiII–tmdta compared to pK a1H = 2.69 for NiII–edta. We have shown in previous work that both NiII–edta and NiII–tmdta contain small amounts of a water-coordinated complex species. As shown before, any edta complex with CN 6 and a fully coordinated ligand contains a certain equilibrium amount of CN 7 species with a coordinated water. For the current case, i.e., protonation of [NiII(edta)]2–, the active species accepting the proton could be seven-coordinate [NiII(edta)(H2O)]2–. The amount of seven-coordinate fraction in the case of NiII–tmdta should be considerably smaller than with NiII–edta, because of stereochemical reasons. This difference is likely responsible for the different pK a1H values (almost two log units) observed for NiII–tmdta and NiII–edta.

Estimation of Complex Stability Constant logβ110 and pK a1H for NiII-tmdta

In previous works we have shown that pH-dependent spectrophotometric titration experiments can be applied to estimate various types of equilibrium constants with the aid of the SPECFIT software developed by Zuberbühler et al. Titration of water-soluble metal chelate complexes with acid accompanied by pH lowering delivers usually equilibrium constants for complex formation and  stepwise protonation constants of appropriate complexes. The conditional equilibrium expressions for the relevant processes valid for NiII-tmdta are given in eqs  and , while the mass balance equations required for quantitative analysis are formulated in eqs  and . The spectrum of the neutral solution containing [NiII(tmdta)]2- is gradually changed upon addition of HClO4conc in small aliquots as shown in Figure a. A fit to the spectra shown in Figure a applying SPECFIT and a three-component model (species [NiII(tmdta)]2-, [NiII(Htmdta)(H2O)]-, and [NiII(H2O)6]2+) delivers the results shown in Figure b and c and Table . The data reported in Table  reveals a good agreement between our constants and those given in the literature, in particular considering that the literature values were determined at an ionic strength I = 0.1 M (K+ containing supporting electrolyte, 25 °C) while our data were measured at an ionic strength of I = 1.0 M NaClO4, 25 °C.     [   Ni   II    ( tmdta )  ]   2 -   +   H   3     O   +     ⇄   1 /   K   a 1 H       [   Ni   II    ( Htmdta )   (   H   2   O )  ]   -     5   6     [   Ni   II    ( Htmdta )   (   H   2   O )  ]    -   + 5   H   3     O   +   ⇄    [   Ni   II     (   H   2   O )   6   ]    2 +   +   H   6     tmdta   2 +          [ Ni   (   H   2   O )   6   ]   2 +   +   Htmdta   3 -     ⇄   log ⁡ β    1 1 1       [   Ni   II    ( Htmdta )   (   H   2   O )  ]   -     7       [ Ni   (   H   2   O )   6   ]   2 +   +   tmdta   4 -     ⇄   log ⁡ β    1 1 0       [   Ni   II    ( tmdta )  ]   2 -     8 Our pK a1H for the protonation of [NiII(tmdta)]2- (reverse process of reaction ) is considerably lower than the one originally estimated by Anderegg. In the latter work, equilibrium data were measured by pH potentiometry at 20 °C, I = 0.1 M (KNO3). The authors state that the pK a1H value they evaluated can contain large errors. The pK a1H = 2.69 that we evaluated for NiII-edta is in very good agreement with one given by Higginson (pK a1H = 2.63), who used spectrophotometric titrations for his measurements and  solution conditions identical with ours (I = 1.0 M NaClO4, 25 °C). This shows that our approach is suitable to gain reliable data. A surprising feature of these equilibrium constants that needs explanation is the gap between pK a1H = 0.78 for NiII-tmdta compared to pK a1H = 2.69 for NiII-edta. We have shown in previous work that both NiII-edta and NiII-tmdta contain small amounts of a water-coordinated complex species. As shown before, any edta complex with CN 6 and a fully coordinated ligand contains a certain equilibrium amount of CN 7 species with a coordinated water. For the current case, i.e., protonation of [NiII(edta)]2-, the active species accepting the proton could be seven-coordinate [NiII(edta)(H2O)]2-. The amount of seven-coordinate fraction in the case of NiII-tmdta should be considerably smaller than with NiII-edta, because of stereochemical reasons. This difference is likely responsible for the different pK a1H values (almost two log units) observed for NiII-tmdta and NiII-edta.

The ligand pK a data used during SPECFIT application are collected in Table S4, Supporting Information. Values in parentheses are those given in ref. for 25 °C, I = 0.1 M.

Our study shows in a clear-cut way an adequate strategy to quantify a tb ⇌ hc equilibrium between labile NiII complex species in solution. Experimental structures obtained with X-ray diffraction measurements and DFT-optimized geometries provided limiting structures that served as basis to establish the equilibrium ratio of 40% hc and 60% tb. The latter was estimated by systematic comparisons of experimental IR and Raman spectra with those computed with DFT calculations. Our NMR spectral results are of special interest because it was established for the very first time in a edta-type complex that the λ ⇌ δ glycinate chelate ring interconversions take place with a velocity that is 2 orders of magnitude slower than the analogous process in the central diamine T ring. Furthermore, we developed an approach to determine the solution structure of Ni2+ complexes by analyzing the experimental 13C NMR shifts with the aid of DFT calculations. Our results show that the paramagnetic shifts induced by Ni2+ are dominated by the contact contribution, which can be obtained in a straightforward way by computing isotropic hyperfine coupling constants with the aid of DFT calculations. The contact shifts calculated for the tb and hc isomers are significantly different and therefore can be used to gain information on the populations of these conformers in solution. Analysis of the contact shifts confirms the 40% hc and 60% tb population obtained from analysis of the IR and Raman spectra.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Our study shows in a clear-cut way an adequate strategy to quantify a tb ⇌ hc equilibrium between labile NiII complex species in solution. Experimental structures obtained with X-ray diffraction measurements and DFT-optimized geometries provided limiting structures that served as basis to establish the equilibrium ratio of 40% hc and 60% tb. The latter was estimated by systematic comparisons of experimental IR and Raman spectra with those computed with DFT calculations. Our NMR spectral results are of special interest because it was established for the very first time in a edta-type complex that the λ ⇌ δ glycinate chelate ring interconversions take place with a velocity that is 2 orders of magnitude slower than the analogous process in the central diamine T ring. Furthermore, we  developed an approach to determine the solution structure of Ni2+ complexes by analyzing the experimental 13C NMR shifts with the aid of DFT calculations. Our results show that the paramagnetic shifts induced by Ni2+ are dominated by the contact contribution, which can be obtained in a straightforward way by computing isotropic hyperfine coupling constants with the aid of DFT calculations. The contact shifts calculated for the tb and hc isomers are significantly different and therefore can be used to gain information on the populations of these conformers in solution. Analysis of the contact shifts confirms the 40% hc and 60% tb population obtained from  analysis of the IR and Raman spectra.

elements.content: Recording of solid state and solution spectra of hc and tb complexes reveals that the tb form shows a much greater intensity of the 10 Dq band (3A2g→ 3T2g( F ) transition) than the hc, while the common solution spectrum reflects again the presence of a tb ⇌ hc equilibrium in solution. Equilibrium measurements clarify that [Ni(tmdta)]2– has about the same complex stability compared to Ni(edta)]2–, but the former shows a much greater resistance against protonation as compared to the latter.
elements.clean_text: Recording of solid state and solution spectra of hc and tb complexes reveals that the tb form shows a much greater intensity of the 10 Dq band (3A2g→ 3T2g( F ) transition) than the hc, while the common solution spectrum reflects again the presence of a tb ⇌ hc equilibrium in solution. Equilibrium measurements clarify that [Ni(tmdta)]2- has about the same complex stability compared to Ni(edta)]2-, but the former shows a much greater resistance against protonation as compared to the latter.

elements.content: We believe that the methodology reported in this work represents a valuable tool to establish the solution structures of Ni2+ as well as other transition metal complexes with polyaminocarboxylate ligands, an issue of crucial importance for a better understanding of the reactivity of this important class of compounds. Furthermore, we have shown that the NMR spectra of Ni2+ complexes are dominated by contact shifts that can be accurately predicted with DFT calculations. Extension of the methods reported here to other complexes will allow a more robust characterization of an innovative class of Ni2+-based paramagnetic probes for magnetic resonance imaging that take advantage of the chemical exchange saturation transfer effect (ParaCEST).
elements.clean_text: We believe that the methodology reported in this work represents a valuable tool to establish the solution structures of Ni2+ as well as other transition metal complexes with polyaminocarboxylate ligands, an issue of crucial importance for a better understanding of the reactivity of this important class of compounds. Furthermore, we have shown that the NMR spectra of Ni2+ complexes are dominated by contact shifts that can be accurately predicted with DFT calculations. Extension of the methods reported here to other complexes will allow a more robust characterization of an innovative class of Ni2+-based paramagnetic probes for magnetic resonance imaging that take advantage of the chemical exchange saturation transfer effect (ParaCEST).

elements.content: Crystal data and structure refinement details, additional structural details, comparison of experimental and DFT structures, Dunitz plot for the tb structures, temperature dependence of the 13C NMR chemical shifts, views of the DFT-optimized structures of energy minima and transition states, optimized Cartesian coordinates of energy minima and transition states obtained with DFT computations and X-ray crystallographic data in CIF format. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
